body.p: Il faudrait dire glisser dans la conversation a l'Ambassadeur de Suede afin qu'il cesse de parler d'Armfeldt que Si il étoit en Russie je ne le rend me feroit conscience de le rendre, parceque dans Son affaire au fond je ne voyoit d'autre motif que celui du mecontentement qu'il avoit conçu de ce que le Testament du feu Roy n'avoit pas été rempli, qu'en outre Si l'on me ils parleroit de cet affaire l'on en me renouvellant en me parlant et reparlant de cette affaire on ne faisoit que ramener renouveller a ma memoire une affaire desagreable Sur laquelle de droit je pourroit demander une Satisfaction Sur la maniere peu convenable dont on avoit ce qu'on y avoit osé y nomerCatherine put a bar over the 'm' to indicate a double 'm'. mon nom. Que et que Si j'y avoit eu part comeCatherine put a bar over the 'm' to indicate a double letter. on avoit eu envie de le faire croire et Si je lavoit assisté ou Soutenu Armfeldt on S'en Seroit assurement malheur plus mal trouvé.On fol. 4, there is a note in another hand: 'Ce brouillon est tout entier dela main de l'Imperatrice Catherine'. The assertion that this is a 'draft' is contestable: the letter shows signs of folding in the manner that Catherine used for sending notes within Petersburg. The content is also highly indicative: she is scripting information that she would like one of her ministers, perhaps the head of foreign affairs, A. A. Bezborodko, to 'slip into conversation' with the Swedish representative at her court. Therefore, this letter in fact gives us an important insight into her mode of work: she crosses out and reworks the exact phrasing of what she wants said at diplomatic meetings, even ones that she does not plan to attend. She would have had no reason to make a clean copy of such a note, as it is a working document for herself and her closest advisors: it would presumably have been sent as is.

It must be said slipped into the conversation with the Swedish ambassador, so that he stops talking about Armfeldt, that if he were in Russia, I would not return him have scruples about returning him, for in his case I saw no other motive besides his dissatisfaction with the failure to execute the late King's will. Besides, if one they spoke to me about this matter in renewing in speaking to me again and again about this matter they merely brought back renewed in my memory a disagreable affair, in which I could legitimately demand satisfaction for the most unsuitable manner in which they for having dared to name me. That And if I had been involved, as they wanted to make people believe, and if I had helped him or supported Armfeldt, they would have certainly misfortune have been worse off.
